document.title: Building Side Projects That Actually Teach You Something
document.summary: Practical insights on choosing and finishing side projects.

body.raw:
Most developers start side projects because they want to learn something new — a new framework, a new stack, or just to solve a tiny personal itch.

But here’s the trap: many of those projects never make it past the “setup” phase.

### 1. Pick a Problem That Annoys You

The best projects come from friction. Don’t pick something trendy — pick something that bugs you every week.

### 2. Build in Public

Share progress early. Even a simple “day 1” tweet can keep you accountable and attract feedback.

### 3. Ship Early, Then Improve

Perfect is a moving target. You’ll learn more from feedback on something that exists than from a plan that never leaves your `todo.md`.

### 4. Reflect and Reuse

Every project teaches you a pattern. Reuse code, patterns, or lessons. Side projects compound.

---

The goal isn’t to finish *every* side project.  
The goal is to learn something valuable from *each* one.

document.title: Learning in Public: The Developer’s Cheat Code
document.summary: Why sharing learning publicly can accelerate your growth as a developer.

body.raw:
When you learn in public, you invite feedback, connection, and accountability — the three things that accelerate real progress.

### 1. Teaching Forces Understanding

You don’t fully understand something until you can explain it clearly. Writing about your learning process reveals gaps that tutorials hide.

### 2. It Builds Reputation

When you post solutions, reflections, or even failed attempts, you’re not showing off — you’re building a searchable record of growth.

### 3. The Network Effect

Someone will eventually find your thread or blog post helpful. That “someone” could be your next mentor, employer, or co-founder.

---

Every post you write, no matter how small, plants a seed that compounds into your reputation over time.

document.title: Mastering Asynchronous JavaScript in 2025
document.summary: A modern guide to async/await, promises, and concurrency.

body.raw:
JavaScript used to be infamous for *callback hell*.  
Then Promises arrived. And now, `async/await` has made asynchronous code readable again — if you use it right.

### 1. Understanding the Event Loop

Everything in JavaScript runs on a single thread.  
The trick is — that thread *doesn’t block*. The event loop lets async operations queue callbacks while your code keeps running.

```js
console.log("Start")

setTimeout(() => {
  console.log("Async operation complete")
}, 0)

console.log("End")
```

document.title: On Reading a Research Paper in 2020
document.summary: How to extract real value from academic papers effectively.

body.raw:
Research papers are not for the layman...

They’re written for those who know how to look beyond the abstract.

List example
- one
- two
